The re-opening of the 2020-2021 school year has many challenges during the period of COVID-19. Many technical, logistical and medical advisors will play a major roll in any return to school.

A far more complex issue that will last well beyond COVID-19 is how we choose, as a society and within our school classroom, to deal with the issues of equity and racial injustice. The Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents held a day of learning and self reflection on the challenges and responsibilities to change the trajectory of this insidious pandemic.

Within the M.A.S.S. program, a student panel from Project 351 was welcomed to share their thoughts and perspectives on ‚ÄúWhere Do We Go From Here?‚Äù Their conversation with superintendents was moving and impactful. Their insights can instruct all of us as we look for pathways forward.

We invite you to watch and learn with us!

For those of you who have been with us for the past four years, you know that it is customary for us to post a parody video when school is cancelled. We thought it would be appropriate to bring some levity to these uncertain times. Please enjoy this Hamilton Parody while we continue to work with our Fall Reopening Task Force on plans for the Fall of 2020.

We must enjoy the storms, feel the rain, enjoy the company of others, perfect imperfection, and when the storm is over, search for our rainbow. Instead of fearing the next lightning strike, we must find a way to dance in the rain.

We continue to endure a storm unlike any in the history of Old Colony, and perhaps the world we live in today. Storms will come and they will pass. We must find our opportunities to dance in the rain and know there are rainbows waiting.

Our mindset is everything. We will fill our cups with raindrops so that they are more than half full, and in the words of the late John Lewis, ‚ÄúDo not get lost in a sea of despair. Be hopeful, be optimistic.‚Äù

When it‚Äôs vain to try to dodge it,

But don‚Äôt let your nerve desert you;
Keep yourself in fighting trim.
If the worst is bound to happen,
Spite of all that you can do,

When with troubles you‚Äôre beset,
But remember you are facing

Don‚Äôt give up, whate‚Äôer you do;

See it through!

We've got you covered: Searching for a way to assist in the efforts to provide health care professionals with PPE due to the inability to purchase supplies, members of the Vocational staff at Old Colony RVTHS began 3D printing visors to create face shields, which guard medical professionals against pathogens. Using an opensource file and 3D printers, Machine & Tool Instructor Ralph Blackburn, Electronics Engineering Instructor Dan Brush, and CAD Drafting Instructors Al Amaral and Bryan Sylvia began printing. Each visor takes approximately 4 hours to produce. Once printed, it is then assembled into the shield using paracord, PVC transparent film, and self-adhesive foam. These shields have been, and will continue to be, donated to local health care workers in need.
